did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.physdesc: This collection consists of two record storage boxes, a Hollinger box and one flat box.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The current five years of minutes are restricted to Club members only.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The current five years of minutes are restricted to Club members only.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Spotswood Garden Club Papers, Collection #3090, Special Collections, Carrier Library, James Madison University, Harrisonburg, Va.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: The Spotswood Garden Club was founded in Harrisonburg in 1924, with twenty-four charter members and Mrs. James C. Johnston as president. The goals of the club were "the culture and study of flowers, to aid in conservation of forests, native shrubs, wildflowers and birds, and to foster civic improvements." In 1929, the club was elected to membership in the Garden Club of Virginia, and has frequently participated in that organization's annual Historic Garden Week by securing the cooperation of owners of historic homes in the area to open those homes and grounds for public appreciation. Community work has been an important focus through the years. The club emphasized "Victory Gardens" during World War II and later worked for legislation to remove unsightly billboards. It has sponsored a variety of activities to enhance appreciation of native wildflowers, and has planted gardens at nursing homes, schools, hospitals, cemeteries, and throughout the city. Spotswood Garden Club has also sponsored or co-sponsored many flower shows. In 1983 the club undertook the restoration of the historic garden at Fort Harrison in Dayton, including its continuing maintenance. In 1991 the club joined Greener Harrisonburg and intensified its city beautification efforts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of minutes, files, and scrapbooks, 1924-2001.
